2104    /**
2105     *  Repeats the given char {@code repeat} to form a new String. The table
2106     *  below shows the various  result for some argument combinations.<br>
2107     *  <br><code>
2108     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;0&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2109     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;3&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;"aaa"<br>
2110     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;-2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2111     *  </code>
2112     *
2113     *  @param  c   The character to repeat.
2114     *  @param  repeat  The number of times to repeat {@code c}; a negative
2115     *      value will be treated as zero.
2116     *  @return A new String consisting of the given character repeated
2117     *      {@code repeat} times, or the empty String if {@code repeat} was 0
2118     *      or negative.
2119     *
2120     *  @see String#repeat(int)
2121     *
2122     *  @since 0.0.5
2123     */
2124    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2125    public static final String repeat( final char c, final int repeat )
2126    {
2127        final var retValue = (repeat > 0 ? Character.toString( c ).repeat( repeat ) : EMPTY_STRING).intern();
2128
2129        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2130        return retValue;
2131    }   //  repeat()
2132
2133    /**
2134     *  Repeats the given char {@code repeat}, identified by its code point, to
2135     *  form a new String. The
2136     *  table below shows the various  result for some argument
2137     *  combinations.<br>
2138     *  <br><code>
2139     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;0&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2140     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;3&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;"aaa"<br>
2141     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;-2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2142     *  </code>
2143     *
2144     *  @param  codePoint   The character to repeat.
2145     *  @param  repeat  The number of times to repeat {@code c}; a negative
2146     *      value will be treated as zero.
2147     *  @return A new String consisting of the given character repeated
2148     *      {@code repeat} times, or the empty String if {@code repeat} was 0
2149     *      or negative, or {@code null} if the code point is invalid.
2150     *
2151     *  @see Character#isValidCodePoint(int)
2152     *  @see String#repeat(int)
2153     *
2154     *  @since 0.0.5
2155     */
2156    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2157    public static final String repeat( final int codePoint, final int repeat )
2158    {
2159        final var retValue = (repeat > 0)
2160            ? isValidCodePoint( codePoint )
2161                ? Character.toString( codePoint ).repeat( repeat ).intern()
2162                : null
2163            : EMPTY_STRING;
2164
2165        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2166        return retValue;
2167    }   //  repeat()
2168
2169    /**
2170     *  Repeats the given String {@code repeat} times to form a new String. The
2171     *  table below shows the various  result for some argument
2172     *  combinations.<br>
2173     *  <br><code>
2174     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;null,&nbsp;2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;null<br>
2175     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"",&nbsp;0&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2176     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"",&nbsp;2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2177     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"a",&nbsp;3&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;"aaa"<br>
2178     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"ab",&nbsp;2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;"abab"<br>
2179     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"a",&nbsp;-2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2180     *  </code>
2181     *
2182     *  @param  s The String to repeat, may be {@code null}.
2183     *  @param repeat   The number of times to repeat {@code str}; a negative
2184     *      value will be treated as zero.
2185     *  @return A new String consisting of the original String repeated,
2186     *      {@code repeat} times, the empty String if {@code repeat} was 0
2187     *      or negative, or {@code null} if the input String was
2188     *      {@code null}, too.
2189     *
2190     *  @see String#repeat(int)
2191     *
2192     *  @since 0.0.5
2193     */
2194    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2195    public static final String repeat( final CharSequence s, final int repeat )
2196    {
2197        final var retValue =
2198            nonNull( s )
2199                ? (repeat > 0) && !s.isEmpty()
2200                    ? s.toString().repeat( repeat )
2201                    : EMPTY_STRING
2202                : null;
2203
2204        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2205        return retValue;
2206    }   //  repeat()
2207
2208    /**
2209     *  Replaces the variables of the form <code>${&lt;<i>name</i>&gt;}</code>
2210     *  in the given String with values from the given maps. The method will
2211     *  try the maps in the given sequence.<br>
2212     *  <br>If no replacement value could be found, the variable will not be
2213     *  replaced at all.<br>
2214     *  <br>If a value from one of the maps contains a variable itself, this
2215     *  will not be replaced.<br>
2216     *  <br>The variables names are case-sensitive.<br>
2217     *  <br>Valid variable name may not contain other characters than the
2218     *  letters from 'a' to 'z' (upper case and lower case), the digits from
2219     *  '0' to '9' and the special characters underscore ('_') and dot ('.'),
2220     *  after an optional prefix character.<br>
2221     *  <br>Allowed prefixes are the tilde ('~'), the slash ('/'), the equal
2222     *  sign ('='), the colon (':'), the percent sign ('%'), and the ampersand
2223     *  ('&amp;').<br>
2224     *  <br>The prefix character is part of the name.<br>
2225     *  <br>Finally, there is the single underscore that is allowed as a
2226     *  special variable.
2227     *
2228     *  @param  text    The text with the variables; may be {@code null}.
2229     *  @param  sources The maps with the replacement values.
2230     *  @return The new text, or {@code null} if the provided value for
2231     *      {@code text} was already {@code null}.
2232     *
2233     *  @see #VARIABLE_PATTERN
2234     *
2235     *  @since 0.0.5
2236     *  @deprecated Use
2237     *      {@link Template#replaceVariable(CharSequence, Map[])}
2238     *      instead.
2239     */
2240    @SafeVarargs
2241    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2242    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2243    public static final String replaceVariable( final CharSequence text, final Map<String,? extends Object>... sources )
2244    {
2245        return Template.replaceVariable( text, sources );
2246    }   //  replaceVariable()
2247
2248    /**
2249     *  Replaces the variables of the form <code>${&lt;<i>name</i>&gt;}</code>
2250     *  in the given String with values returned by the given retriever
2251     *  function for the variable name.<br>
2252     *  <br>If no replacement value could be found, the variable will not be
2253     *  replaced at all.<br>
2254     *  <br>If the retriever function returns a value that contains a variable
2255     *  itself, this will not be replaced.<br>
2256     *  <br>The retriever function will be called only once for each variable
2257     *  name; if the text contains the same variable multiple times, it will
2258     *  always be replaced with the same value.<br>
2259     *  <br>The variables names are case-sensitive.<br>
2260     *  <br>Valid variable name may not contain other characters than the
2261     *  letters from 'a' to 'z' (upper case and lower case), the digits from
2262     *  '0' to '9' and the special characters underscore ('_') and dot ('.'),
2263     *  after an optional prefix character.<br>
2264     *  <br>Allowed prefixes are the tilde ('~'), the slash ('/'), the equal
2265     *  sign ('='), the colon (':'), the percent sign ('%'), and the ampersand
2266     *  ('&amp;').<br>
2267     *  <br>The prefix character is part of the name.<br>
2268     *  <br>Finally, there is the single underscore that is allowed as a
2269     *  special variable.
2270     *
2271     *  @param  text    The text with the variables; may be {@code null}.
2272     *  @param  retriever   The function that will retrieve the replacement
2273     *      values for the given variable names.
2274     *  @return The new text, or {@code null} if the provided value for
2275     *      {@code text} was already {@code null}.
2276     *
2277     *  @see #VARIABLE_PATTERN
2278     *
2279     *  @since 0.0.5
2280     *  @deprecated Use
2281     *      {@link Template#replaceVariable(CharSequence, Function)}
2282     *      instead.
2283     */
2284    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2285    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2286    public static final String replaceVariable( final CharSequence text, final Function<? super String, Optional<String>> retriever )
2287    {
2288        return Template.replaceVariable( text, retriever );
2289    }   //  replaceVariable()
2290
2291    /**
2292     *  Splits a String by the given separator character and returns an array
2293     *  of all parts. In case a separator character is immediately followed by
2294     *  another separator char, an empty String will be place to the array.
2295     *  Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
2296     *  first character of the String is a separator, the returned array will
2297     *  start with an empty string, as it will end with an empty String if the
2298     *  last character is a separator.<br>
2299     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be an array
2300     *  containing just the empty String.
2301     *
2302     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2303     *  @param  separator   The separator character.
2304     *  @return The parts of the String.
2305     *
2306     *  @since 0.0.5
2307     */
2308    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2309    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence string, final char separator )
2310    {
2311        return splitString( string, (int) separator );
2312    }   //  splitString()
2313
2314    /**
2315     *  Splits a String by the given separator character, identified by its
2316     *  Unicode code point, and returns an array of all parts. In case a
2317     *  separator character is immediately followed by another separator char,
2318     *  an empty String will be placed to the array. Beginning and end of the
2319     *  String are treated as separators, so if the first character of the
2320     *  String is a separator, the returned array will start with an empty
2321     *  String, as it will end with an empty String if the last character is a
2322     *  separator.<br>
2323     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be an array
2324     *  containing just the empty String.
2325     *
2326     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2327     *  @param  separator   The code point for the separator character.
2328     *  @return The parts of the String.
2329     *
2330     *  @since 0.0.5
2331     */
2332    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2333    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence string, final int separator )
2334    {
2335        final var retValue = stream( string, separator ).toArray( String []::new );
2336
2337        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2338        return retValue;
2339    }   //  splitString()

2341    /**
2342     *  Splits a String by the given separator sequence and returns an array
2343     *  of all parts. In case a separator sequence is immediately followed by
2344     *  another separator sequence, an empty String will be placed to the
2345     *  array. Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if
2346     *  the first part of the String equals the separator sequence, the
2347     *  returned array will start with an empty String, as it will end with an
2348     *  empty string if the last part would equal the separator sequence..<br>
2349     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be an array
2350     *  containing just the empty String.
2351     *
2352     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2353     *  @param  separator   The separator sequence.
2354     *  @return The parts of the String.
2355     *
2356     *  @since 0.0.5
2357     */
2358    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2359    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence string, final CharSequence separator )
2360    {
2361        final var retValue = stream( string, separator).toArray( String []::new );
2362
2363        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2364        return retValue;
2365    }   //  splitString()
2366
2367    /**
2368     *  Splits a String by the given separator character and returns a
2369     *  {@link Stream}
2370     *  of all parts. In case a separator character is immediately followed by
2371     *  another separator char, an empty String will be put to the
2372     *  {@code Stream}. Beginning and end of the String are treated as
2373     *  separators, so if the first character of the String is a separator, the
2374     *  returned {@code Stream} will start with an empty String, as it will end
2375     *  with an empty String if the last character is a separator.<br>
2376     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2377     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String.
2378     *
2379     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2380     *  @param  separator   The separator character.
2381     *  @return A {@code Stream} instance with the parts of the String.
2382     *
2383     *  @since 0.0.7
2384     */
2385    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2386    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence string, final char separator )
2387    {
2388        return stream( string, (int) separator );
2389    }   //  stream()
2390
2391    /**
2392     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator character, identified by its
2393     *  Unicode code point, and returns a
2394     *  {@link Stream}
2395     *  of all parts.} In case a separator character is immediately followed by
2396     *  another separator char, an empty String will be put to the
2397     *  {@code Stream}. Beginning and end of the String are treated as
2398     *  separators, so if the first character of the String is a separator, the
2399     *  returned {@code Stream} will start with an empty String, as it will end
2400     *  with an empty String if the last character is a separator.</p>
2401     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2402     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String.</p>
2403     *
2404     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2405     *  @param  separator   The code point for the separator character.
2406     *  @return A {@code Stream} instance with the parts of the String.
2407     *
2408     *  @since 0.0.7
2409     */
2410    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2411    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence string, final int separator )
2412    {
2413        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
2414        final var s = requireNonNullArgument( string, "string" ).codePoints().toArray();
2415        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
2416        var begin = -1;
2417        for( var i = 0 ; i < s.length; ++i )
2418        {
2419            if( begin == -1 )
2420            {
2421                begin = i;
2422            }
2423            if( s [ i ] == separator )
2424            {
2425                builder.add( new String( s, begin, i - begin ).intern() );
2426                begin = -1;
2427            }
2428        }
2429
2430        //---* Add the rest *--------------------------------------------------
2431        if( (begin >= 0) && (begin < s.length) )
2432        {
2433            builder.add( new String( s, begin, s.length - begin ).intern() );
2434        }
2435        if( (s.length == 0) || (s [s.length - 1] == separator) )
2436        {
2437            builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2438        }
2439
2440        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
2441        final var retValue = builder.build();
2442
2443        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2444        return retValue;
2445    }   //  stream()
2446
2447    /**
2448     *  Splits a String by the given separator sequence and returns a
2449     *  {@link Stream}
2450     *  of all parts. In case a separator sequence is immediately followed by
2451     *  another separator sequence, an empty String will be put to the
2452     *  {@code Stream}. Beginning and end of the String are treated as
2453     *  separators, so if the first part of the String equals the separator
2454     *  sequence, the returned {@code Stream} will start with an empty string,
2455     *  as it will end with an empty String if the last part would equal the
2456     *  separator sequence.<br>
2457     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2458     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String.
2459     *
2460     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2461     *  @param  separator   The separator sequence.
2462     *  @return The parts of the String.
2463     *
2464     *  @since 0.0.7
2465     */
2466    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2467    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence string, final CharSequence separator )
2468    {
2469        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
2470        var s = requireNonNullArgument( string, "string" ).toString();
2471        final var t = requireNotEmptyArgument( separator, "separator" ).toString();
2472
2473        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
2474        var pos = Integer.MAX_VALUE;
2475        while( isNotEmpty( s ) && (pos >= 0) )
2476        {
2477            pos = s.indexOf( t );
2478            switch( Integer.signum( pos ) )
2479            {
2480                case 0 -> /* String starts with separator */
2481                    {
2482                        builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2483                        s = s.substring( t.length() );
2484                    }
2485                case 1 -> /* String contains a separator somewhere */
2486                    {
2487                        builder.add( s.substring( 0, pos ) );
2488                        s = s.substring( pos + t.length() );
2489                    }
2490                case -1 -> { /* Just leave the loop */ }
2491            }   //  ResultHandlerSwitch:
2492        }
2493
2494        //---* Add the rest *--------------------------------------------------
2495        builder.add( s );
2496
2497        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
2498        final var retValue = builder.build();
2499
2500        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2501        return retValue;
2502    }   //  stream()
2503
2504    /**
2505     *  Splits a String using the given regular expression and returns a
2506     *  {@link Stream}
2507     *  of all parts. In case a separator sequence is immediately followed by
2508     *  another separator sequence, an empty String will be put to the
2509     *  {@code Stream}. Beginning and end of the String are treated as
2510     *  separators, so if the first part of the String equals the separator
2511     *  sequence, the returned {@code Stream} will start with an empty string,
2512     *  as it will end with an empty String if the last part would equal the
2513     *  separator sequence.<br>
2514     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2515     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String.
2516     *
2517     *  @note This method behaves different from
2518     *      {@link String#split(String)}
2519     *      as it will return trailing empty Strings.
2520     *
2521     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2522     *  @param  pattern The separator sequence.
2523     *  @return The parts of the String.
2524     *
2525     *  @see String#split(String)
2526     *  @see Pattern#split(CharSequence)
2527     *
2528     *  @since 0.0.7
2529     */
2530    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2531    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence string, final Pattern pattern )
2532    {
2533        requireNonNullArgument( pattern, "pattern" );
2534
2535        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
2536        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
2537        if( isEmpty( requireNonNullArgument( string, "string" ) ) )
2538        {
2539            builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2540        }
2541        else
2542        {
2543            final var parts = pattern.split( string );
2544            for( final var part : parts )
2545            {
2546                builder.add( part );
2547            }
2548            final var matcher = pattern.matcher( string );
2549            var count = 0;
2550            while( matcher.find() ) ++count;
2551            //noinspection ForLoopWithMissingComponent
2552            for( ; count >= parts.length; --count )
2553            {
2554                builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2555            }
2556        }
2557
2558        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
2559        final var retValue = builder.build();
2560
2561        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2562        return retValue;
2563    }   //  stream()
2564
2565    /**
2566     *  Strips HTML or XML tags from the given String, without touching other
2567     *  entities (like {@code &amp;} or {@code &nbsp;}). The result would be
2568     *  the effective text, stripped from all other whitespace (except single
2569     *  blanks).<br>
2570     *  <br>This means that the result for
2571     *  <pre><code>stripTags( &quot;&lt;html&gt;
2572     *      &lt;head&gt;
2573     *        &hellip;
2574     *      &lt;/head&gt;
2575     *      &lt;body&gt;
2576     *        &lt;a href='&hellip;'&gt;       Simple          &lt;br&gt;
2577     *          &lt;br&gt;           Text       &lt;/a&gt;
2578     *      &lt;/body&gt;
2579     *  &lt;/html&gt;&quot; )</code></pre> would be just
2580     *  &quot;{@code Simple Text}&quot;.<br>
2581     *  <br>Comments will be stripped as well, and {@code <pre>} tags are not
2582     *  interpreted, with the consequence that any formatting with whitespace
2583     *  gets lost. {@code CDATA} elements are stripped, too.
2584     *
2585     *  @param  s   The HTML/XML string.
2586     *  @return The string without the tags.
2587     *
2588     *  @since 0.0.7
2589     */
2590    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2591    public static final String stripTags( final CharSequence s )
2592    {
2593        final var retValue = new StringBuilder();
2594        if( isNotEmptyOrBlank( requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ) ) )
2595        {
2596            final var matcher = m_TagRemovalPattern.matcher( s );
2597            final var buffer = matcher.replaceAll( " " ).trim().codePoints().toArray();
2598            int lastChar = NULL_CHAR;
2599            ScanLoop: for( final var c : buffer )
2600            {
2601                if( isWhitespace( c ) )
2602                {
2603                    //---* Consecutive whitespace detected *-------------------
2604                    if( isWhitespace( lastChar ) ) continue ScanLoop;
2605
2606                    //---* All resulting whitespace have to be blanks *--------
2607                    retValue.append( " " );
2608                }
2609                else
2610                {
2611                    //---* Write the character *-------------------------------
2612                    retValue.append( toChars( c ) );
2613                }
2614                lastChar = c;
2615            }   //  ScanLoop:
2616        }
2617
2618        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2619        return retValue.toString();
2620    }   //  stripTags()
2621
2622    /**
2623     *  Strips characters from the given input that are not allowed (or should
2624     *  be at least avoided) for a file or folder name on most or all operating
2625     *  systems.<br>
2626     *  <br>The following characters will be stripped:
2627     *  <dl>
2628     *  <dt><b>:</b> (colon)</dt><dd>On Windows systems it is used to separate
2629     *  the drive letter from the path and file name; on Unix-like operating
2630     *  systems it would be valid, but it can cause issues on the {@code PATH}
2631     *  and {@code CLASSPATH} variables on that operating systems.</dd>
2632     *  <dt><b>\</b> (backslash)</dt><dd>On Windows systems it is used as the
2633     *  path separator, while on Unix-like operating systems it is problematic
2634     *  in other ways. For example, it is used to escape blanks in not-quoted
2635     *  file or folder names.</dd>
2636     *  <dt><b>/</b> (slash or forward slash)</dt><dd>The path separator on
2637     *  Unix-like operating systems, but Java will use it that way on Windows
2638     *  systems, too.</dd>
2639     *  <dt><b>;</b> (semicolon)</dt><dd>It can cause issues on the {@code PATH}
2640     *  and {@code CLASSPATH} variables on Windows.</dd>
2641     *  <dt><b>*</b> (asterisk)</dt><dd>The asterisk is often used as wild card
2642     *  character in shell programs to find groups of files; using it in a file
2643     *  name can cause funny effects.</dd>
2644     *  <dt><b>?</b> (question mark)</dt><dd>The question mark is used on
2645     *  Windows as a wild card for a single character; similar to the asterisk,
2646     *  it can cause funny effects when used in a file name.</dd>
2647     *  <dt><b>&quot;</b> (double quotes)</dt>
2648     *  <dt><b>'</b> (single quotes)</dt><dd>Both have some potential to
2649     *  confuse the various shell programs of all operating systems.</dd>
2650     *  <dt><b>@</b> ('at'-sign)</dt><dd>Although it is allowed for file and
2651     *  folder names, it causes issues when used in the URL for that respective
2652     *  file.</dd>
2653     *  <dt><b>|</b> (pipe symbol)</dt><dd>Similar to the '*' (asterisk), the
2654     *  pipe-symbol has â as the name already indicates - a meaning on most
2655     *  shells that would make it difficult to manage files that contains this
2656     *  character in their names.</dd>
2657     *  <dt><b>&lt;</b> (less than)</dt>
2658     *  <dt><b>&gt;</b> (greater than)</dt><dd>Like the pipe, these two have a
2659     *  meaning on most shells that would make it difficult to manage files
2660     *  that contains one of these characters in their names.</dd>
2661     *  <dt>Whitespace</dt><dd>Only blanks will remain, any other whitespace
2662     *  characters are stripped.</dd>
2663     *  </dl>
2664     *  Finally, the method will strip all leading and trailing blanks;
2665     *  although blanks are usually allowed, they are confusing when not
2666     *  surrounded by some visible characters.
2667     *  Especially regarding the characters that are critical for shells ('*',
2668     *  '?', '&quot;', ''', '|', '&lt;', and '&gt;') this method is
2669     *  over-cautious, as most shells could handle them after proper escaping
2670     *  the offending characters or quoting the file name.<br>
2671     *  <br>This method furthermore assumes that any other Unicode character is
2672     *  valid for a file or folder name; unfortunately, there are filesystems
2673     *  where this is not true.
2674     *
2675     *  @note   This method will not take care about the length of the returned
2676     *      String; this means the result to a call to this method may still be
2677     *      invalid as a file or folder name because it is too long.
2678     *
2679     *  @param  s   The input String, denoting a file or folder name -
2680     *      <i>not</i> a full path.
2681     *  @return The String without the characters that are invalid for a file
2682     *      name. This value will never be {@code null} or empty.
2683     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The input is {@code null}.
2684     *  @throws EmptyArgumentException  The input is the empty String.
2685     *  @throws ValidationException After stripping the invalid characters the
2686     *      return value would be empty.
2687     *
2688     *  @since 0.0.5
2689     */
2690    @SuppressWarnings( "SwitchStatementWithTooManyBranches" )
2691    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2692    public static final String stripToFilename( final CharSequence s ) throws ValidationException
2693    {
2694        final var len = requireNotEmptyArgument( s, "s" ).length();
2695        final var buffer = new StringBuilder( len );
2696        char c;
2697        ScanLoop: for( var i = 0; i < len; ++i )
2698        {
2699            c = s.charAt( i );
2700            Selector: switch( c )
2701            {
2702                case ':':
2703                case '\\':
2704                case '/':
2705                case ';':
2706                case '*':
2707                case '"':
2708                case '\'':
2709                case '@':
2710                case '|':
2711                case '?':
2712                case '<':
2713                case '>':
2714                    continue ScanLoop;
2715
2716                default:
2717                {
2718                    if( (c == ' ') || (!isISOControl( c ) && !isWhitespace( c )) )
2719                    {
2720                        buffer.append( c );
2721                    }
2722                    break Selector;
2723                }
2724            }   //  Selector:
2725        }   //  ScanLoop:
2726
2727        final var retValue = buffer.toString().trim();
2728        if( retValue.length() < 1 )
2729        {
2730            throw new ValidationException( format( "After stripping the invalid characters from '%1$s' there do not remain enough characters for a valid file name", s.toString() ) );
2731        }
2732
2733        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2734        return retValue;
2735    }   //  stripToFilename()
2736
2737    /**
2738     *  Strips HTML or XML comments from the given String.
2739     *
2740     *  @param  s   The HTML/XML string.
2741     *  @return The string without the comments.
2742     *
2743     *  @since 0.0.5
2744     */
2745    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2746    public static final String stripXMLComments( final CharSequence s )
2747    {
2748        final var matcher = m_CommentRemovalPattern.matcher( requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ) );
2749        final var retValue = matcher.replaceAll( EMPTY_STRING );
2750
2751        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2752        return retValue;
2753    }   //  stripXMLComments()
2754
2755    /**
2756     *  Translates the given String to a String that will only contain
2757     *  printable ASCII characters; all other characters will be 'escaped' to
2758     *  the format &quot;&#92;uXXXX&quot;.
2759     *
2760     *  @param  s   The input string; may be {@code null}.
2761     *  @return The output string; {@code null} if the input string was
2762     *      already {@code null}.
2763     *
2764     *  @since 0.0.5
2765     *  @deprecated Use instead
2766     *      {@link CharSetUtils#convertUnicodeToASCII(java.text.Normalizer.Form, CharSequence)}
2767     *      with
2768     *      {@link java.text.Normalizer.Form#NFKC}
2769     *      as the first argument.
2770     */
2771    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2772    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2773    public static final String toUnicode( final CharSequence s )
2774    {
2775        return CharSetUtils.convertUnicodeToASCII( NFKC, s );

2778    /**
2779     *  Changes the first letter of the given String tolower case as per
2780     *  {@link Character#toLowerCase(char)}.
2781     *  No other letters are changed. A {@code null} input String returns
2782     *  {@code null}.<br>
2783     *  <br>Samples:<pre><code>  StringUtils.uncapitalize( null ) = null;
2784     *  StringUtils.uncapitalize(&quot;&quot;)     = &quot;&quot;;
2785     *  StringUtils.uncapitalize(&quot;Cat&quot;)  = &quot;cat&quot;;
2786     *  StringUtils.uncapitalize(&quot;CAT&quot;)  = &quot;cAT&quot;;</code></pre>
2787     *  <br>Basically, this is the complementary method to
2788     *  {@link #capitalize(CharSequence)}.
2789     *  Use this method to normalise the name of bean attributes.
2790     *
2791     *  @param  s   The String to <i>uncapitalise</i>, may be {@code null}.
2792     *  @return The <i>uncapitalised</i> String, {@code null} if the argument
2793     *      was {@code null}.
2794     *  @see #capitalize(CharSequence)
2795     *
2796     *  @since 0.0.5
2797     *  @deprecated Use
2798     *      {@link #decapitalize(CharSequence)}
2799     *      instead.
2800     */
2801    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0" )
2802    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2803    public static final String uncapitalize( final CharSequence s ) { return decapitalize( s ); }
2804
2805    /**
2806     *  Unescapes a string containing entity escapes to a string containing the
2807     *  actual Unicode characters corresponding to the escapes. Supports HTML
2808     *  5.0 entities.<br>
2809     *  <br>For example, the string
2810     *  &quot;&amp;lt;Fran&amp;ccedil;ais&amp;gt;&quot; will become
2811     *  &quot;&lt;Fran&ccedil;ais&gt;&quot;.<br>
2812     *  <br>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2813     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2814     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.
2815     *
2816     *  @param  str The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2817     *  @return A new unescaped {@code String}, {@code null} if the given
2818     *      string was already {@code null}.
2819     *
2820     *  @see #escapeHTML(CharSequence)
2821     *  @see #escapeHTML(Appendable,CharSequence)
2822     *
2823     *  @since 0.0.5
2824     */
2825    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2826    public static final String unescapeHTML( final CharSequence str )
2827    {
2828        final var retValue = nonNull( str ) ? HTML50.unescape( str ) : null;
2829
2830        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2831        return retValue;
2832    }   //  unescapeHTML()
2833
2834    /**
2835     *  Unescapes a string containing entity escapes to a string containing the
2836     *  actual Unicode characters corresponding to the escapes and writes it to
2837     *  the given
2838     *  {@link Appendable}.
2839     *  Supports HTML 4.0 entities.<br>
2840     *  <br>For example, the string
2841     *  &quot;&amp;lt;Fran&amp;ccedil;ais&amp;gt;&quot; will become
2842     *  &quot;&lt;Fran&ccedil;ais&gt;&quot;.<br>
2843     *  <br>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2844     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2845     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.
2846     *
2847     *  @param  appendable  The appendable receiving the unescaped string.
2848     *  @param  str The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2849     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The appendable is {@code null}.
2850     *  @throws IOException An IOException occurred.
2851     *
2852     *  @see #escapeHTML(CharSequence)
2853     *
2854     *  @since 0.0.5
2855     */
2856    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2857    public static final void unescapeHTML( final Appendable appendable, final CharSequence str ) throws IOException
2858    {
2859        requireNonNullArgument( appendable, "appendable" );
2860
2861        if( nonNull( str ) ) HTML50.unescape( appendable, str );
2862    }   //  unescapeHTML()
2863
2864    /**
2865     *  Parses Strings in the format &quot;<code>&#92;uXXXX</code>&quot;,
2866     *  containing the textual representation of a single Unicode character, to
2867     *  the respective Unicode character. Some Unicode characters will be
2868     *  represented as <i>surrogate pairs</i> in Java, so the String that is
2869     *  returned by this method may contain more than one {@code char}.<br>
2870     *  <br>The input format for this method is used in Java source code
2871     *  Strings, in Java {@code .properties} files, in C/C++ source code, in
2872     *  JavaScript source, &hellip;
2873     *
2874     *  @param  s   The input String with the Unicode escape sequence.
2875     *  @return The Unicode character.
2876     *  @throws ValidationException The input is {@code null}, empty, or cannot
2877     *      be parsed as a unicode escape sequence.
2878     *
2879     *  @since 0.0.5
2880     *  @deprecated Use
2881     *      {@link CharSetUtils#unescapeUnicode(CharSequence)}
2882     *      instead.
2883     */
2884    @Deprecated( since ="0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2885    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2886    public static final String unescapeUnicode( final CharSequence s )
2887    {
2888        return CharSetUtils.unescapeUnicode( s );
2889    }   //  unescapeUnicode()
2890
2891    /**
2892     *  <p>{@summary Unescapes an XML string containing XML entity escapes to a
2893     *  string containing the actual Unicode characters corresponding to the
2894     *  escapes.}</p>
2895     *  <p>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2896     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2897     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.</p>
2898     *
2899     *  @param  str The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2900     *  @return A new unescaped {@code String}, {@code null} if the given
2901     *      string was already {@code null}.
2902     *
2903     *  @see #escapeXML(CharSequence)
2904     *  @see #escapeXML(Appendable,CharSequence)
2905     *
2906     *  @since 0.0.5
2907     */
2908    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2909    public static final String unescapeXML( final CharSequence str )
2910    {
2911        final var retValue = nonNull( str ) ? XML.unescape( str ) : null;
2912
2913        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2914        return retValue;
2915    }   //  unescapeXML()
2916
2917    /**
2918     *  <p>{@summary Unescapes an XML String containing XML entity escapes to a
2919     *  String containing the actual Unicode characters corresponding to the
2920     *  escapes and writes it to the given
2921     *  {@link Appendable}.}</p>
2922     *  <p>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2923     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2924     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.</p>
2925     *
2926     *  @param  appendable  The appendable receiving the unescaped string.
2927     *  @param  str The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2928     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The writer is {@code null}.
2929     *  @throws IOException An IOException occurred.
2930     *
2931     *  @see #escapeXML(CharSequence)
2932     *
2933     *  @since 0.0.5
2934     */
2935    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2936    public static final void unescapeXML( final Appendable appendable, final CharSequence str ) throws IOException
2937    {
2938        requireNonNullArgument( appendable, "appendable" );
2939
2940        if( nonNull( str ) ) XML.unescape( appendable, str );
2941    }   //  unescapeXML()
2942
2943    /**
2944     *  Returns the Unicode escape sequence for the given character. This will
2945     *  return &quot;&#92;u0075&quot; for the letter 'u', and
2946     *  &quot;&#92;u003c&quot; for the smaller-than sign '&lt;'.
2947     *
2948     *  @param  c   The character.
2949     *  @return The escape sequence.
2950     *
2951     *  @deprecated Use
2952     *      {@link CharSetUtils#escapeCharacter(char)}
2953     *      instead.
2954     *
2955     *  @since 0.0.5
2956     */
2957    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2958    @Deprecated( forRemoval = true )
2959    public static final String unicodeEscape( final char c ) { return escapeCharacter( c ); }
2960
2961    /**
2962     *  Returns the Unicode escape sequence for the given code point. This will
2963     *  return &quot;&#92;u0075&quot; for the letter 'u', and
2964     *  &quot;&#92;u003c&quot; for the smaller-than sign '&lt;'.
2965     *
2966     *  @param  codePoint   The character.
2967     *  @return The escape sequence.
2968     *
2969     *  @deprecated Use
2970     *      {@link #escapeUnicode(int)}
2971     *      instead.
2972     *
2973     *  @since 0.0.5
2974     */
2975    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2976    @Deprecated( forRemoval = true )
2977    public static final String unicodeEscape( final int codePoint ) { return escapeUnicode( codePoint ); }
2978
2979    /**
2980     *  Returns the given URL encoded String in its decoded form, using the
2981     *  UTF-8 character encoding.<br>
2982     *  <br>Internally, this method and
2983     *  {@link #urlEncode(CharSequence)}
2984     *  make use of the methods from
2985     *  {@link java.net.URLDecoder}
2986     *  and
2987     *  {@link java.net.URLEncoder}, respectively. The methods here were
2988     *  introduced to simplify the handling, as first only the UTF-8 encoding
2989     *  should be used - making the second argument for the methods
2990     *  {@link java.net.URLDecoder#decode(String, String) decode()}/
2991     *  {@link java.net.URLEncoder#encode(String, String) encode()}
2992     *  obsolete - and second, they could throw an
2993     *  {@link UnsupportedEncodingException} - although this should never occur
2994     *  when UTF-8 encoding is used.
2995     *
2996     *  @param  s   The input String.
2997     *  @return The decoded result.
2998     *
2999     *  @see java.net.URLDecoder#decode(String, String)
3000     *
3001     *  @since 0.0.5
3002     */
3003    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
3004    public static final String urlDecode( final CharSequence s )
3005    {
3006        final var retValue = decode( requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ).toString(), UTF8 );
3007
3008        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
3009        return retValue;
3010    }   //  urlDecode()
3011
3012    /**
3013     *  Returns the given String in its URL encoded form, using the
3014     *  UTF-8 character encoding.
3015     *
3016     *  @param  s   The input String.
3017     *  @return The URL encoded result.
3018     *
3019     *  @see java.net.URLEncoder#encode(String, String)
3020     *  @see #urlDecode(CharSequence)
3021     *
3022     *  @since 0.0.5
3023     */
3024    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
3025    public static final String urlEncode( final CharSequence s )
3026    {
3027        final var retValue = encode( requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ).toString(), UTF8 );
3028
3029        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
3030        return retValue;
3031    }   //  urlEncode()
3032}
